replies.name: T
replies.comment info:
@Edward Jordan 
The graph isn't about sales. The graph is about greenhouse emissions in the United States, and what are the biggest sources of those emissions. One could argue that the increased emissions from transportation may be due to more cars being sold, but without additional data, it's impossible to link this graph directly to sales.

name: Ethan, Pinkey
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: I notice that trains are one of the biggest producers of greenhouse gasses but that makes me wonder if everyone used trains as transportation instead of passenger vehicles and cars would cutting out everyone's individual modes of transportation and replacing them with public transportation would this large contributor of greenhouse gasses still be better than all of the passenger vehicles? Trains will always run no matter if there is 1 or 100 people on them so if more people used this mode of transportation would it cancel out or benefit the planet? I don't know the answer to this but it would be interesting to know because public transportation has always been the "environmentally friendly" way to go.

replies.name: S
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
replies.comment info: @Ethan, Pinkey I liked your point about how trains run regardless of how many people ride them. If people switched to personal modes of transportation like Uber of Lyft, carbon and greenhouse gas emission would surely be reduced. Car-pooling is also an efficient way to reduce emissions because it saves the amount of trips one has to take to get to a certain place. Airplanes and ships will run even if there are only a few people on them, mostly to transport cargo from place to place, but the transportation of goods is, of course, necessary for the operations of the world’s companies.

replies.comment info:
HI, @TEC Devin Dunagan --

Thank you for your notice and wonder.

Take another look at the graphs.  They are two different types of graphs.  The one on the left is a line graph and the one on the right is a stacked area graph.  You can read about the difference in the Stat Nuggets that are below this graph.

Now, reconsider your notice "trains, planes and ships produce the most greenhouse gases out of all transportation methods."  What do you notice now?

Have a catchy headline to share with us that captures the main idea of the graphs?

name: Abby AOSE
comment info:
Headline: Greenhouse Gases

I notice that the highest producer is electricity with 2.5 billion metric tons. I also notice how in 1990 everything is low er until between 1990 and 2017 when it seems to have increased a lot. However, it then goes back down in 2017. In addition, I noticed how transportation is the second-highest, while the industry is the third. Also, agriculture is at the lowest point. 

I wonder how vehicles are actually at the bottom while trains, planes, and ships are above everything. Also, why does nothing hit the 2.5 billion line, and barley hits the 2.0 billion line? Are Greenhouse gases bad for the environment? How are these statistics measured?

name: Kim Barbaro
comment info:
My 6th grade students had the following wonders about these graphs:
-What would the graph look like if it showed 2018 and 2019?
-Why when industry goes down, does transportation go up?
-How will this graph change in the future?
-How would this graph look if you did it for the whole world?
-What does this data look like before 1990?  Was it consistent with these results?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Kim Barbaro --

What a great set of wonderings about this graph.  I wondered why the New York Times showed only  1990 to 2017.  So, I search online for the source in the Environmental Protection Agency and found this these Fast Facts (https://tinyurl.com/qlrmk7r) that summarize the data they collected.  Here's the data they used.  I believe there are data for before 1990, but we will have to wait for data after 2017.
How about a headline that captures the main idea of these graphs?

replies.comment info:
Hi, @TEC, Elijah Torre I --

You ask "what caused the dip in carbon emissions around the 2000's."  It was caused mainly by the financial crisis in 2008.  I wish there were more dates marked on the x-axis so we could see if 2008 was when the dip started.

Have a catchy headline that captures the main idea of these graphs?

name: Brigid
comment info:
What I noticed-

I noticed that electricity was the leading producer of greenhouse gases and was in about the 2.5 billion metric tons area at one point. I also noticed that in 2017 transportation has started to pull ahead of electricity in the amount of greenhouse gases it has produced. I noticed that industry is in third place for the most gases produced. I also noticed how agriculture has been steadily at the bottom of the top greenhouse gas producer list. For the graph on the right I noticed that the passenger vehicles were one of the bottom producers of greenhouse gases and that it seemed like the trains, planes, ships, and other seemed at the top of the transportation greenhouse gas emission. When the trucks were in the middle of the transportation emission of greenhouse gasses.

comment info:

name: Sharon
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas:  “What's Warming Up The Greenhouse?” by Nicole and Luke of Communications High School in Wall, New Jersey, “Greenhouse Gas Culprits” by Claire of Eden Prairie High School, and “The Alarming Production of Greenhouse Gasses” by Kahlvyn of Clarke.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, November 21 - to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be moderated on Wednesday, December 4.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”.  The topic will be immigrants and crime.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph. 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who lives in New England but does not create any greenhouse gas emissions while “going over the river and through the woods” for Thanksgiving, and Annie Fetter of Rutledge, Pennsylvania, who usually bikes almost everywhere, but is taking Amtrak to her family Thanksgiving gathering.

name: Marina W
comment info: I notice that the top sources of greenhouse gases in the United States goes from electricity then transportation then industry and lastly agriculture. Electricity reaches almost about 2.5 billion metric tons. I also notice that trains, planes, ships, and other are the highest on the graph reaching about 2 billion. Then trucks and then passenger vehicles follow the trains, planes, ships, and other. I wonder why electricity is the highest and I wonder why trains, planes, ships, and others are also the highest. I wonder why agriculture and passenger vehicle are the lowest. In this graph it shows the top sources of greenhouse gases in the United States from the year of 1990 to 2017. A catchy headline for this graph could be "Who/What Uses the Most Gas in the US."

replies.comment info: Hi, @Marina W.  How would your thinking change if you knew that passenger cars is actually the biggest transportation-related producer of greenhouse gases?  The stacked area graph adds each category on top of the other one. They don't overlap. It can be confusing for sure! Revisit that graph and see what you notice now.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Marina W very nice explanation I agree with your wonder as well which is kinda weird why Trains, planes, and ship are the highest in electricity.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Marina W 
Even though transportation was lower than electricity in most years, I noticed that in 2017, Electricity dropped and Transportation rose. After 2017, Transportation was the top source of greenhouse gasses.

comment info:

name: Lauren
comment info:
I'm a teacher and wondering how my class joins the American Statistical Association discussion from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.

replies.comment info:

Hope that helps!

name: Renata AOSE
comment info: This graph shows the main sources of high greenhouse gas levels in the United States, as mentioned by the title. replies.comment info: Hi, @Renata AOSE.  I wonder what you made of the right hand graph.  Did the information in that stacked area graph surprise you at all?

name: Brianna C
comment info: This graph shows that the second leading source of greenhouse gases in the United States is transportation. After reading the first side of the graph, the question is what types of transportation cause this. The second graph shows that passenger vehicles, trucks, and other types of transportation all play a large part in gas production. I wonder where this gas goes and if there is an inexpensive way to lower the gas production. I notice that the industrial gas production has slightly decreased along with electricity, unlike transportation. Title: Transportation Makes Mark on World

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Brianna C.  Nice noticings!  You're right that electricity was our highest source of greenhouse gases.  But what happened in 2017?

Since this is a graph about greenhouse gas sources in the US, how would you change your headline to reflect that?  I wonder if you can find data that shows whether or not this pattern is the same in other places besides the United States.  Let us know!

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Brianna C I really like your catchy title and I feel like it really portrays this graph! I also wonder if there is a less expensive way to lower gas production. Possibly if the demand for gas was lower companies wouldn't be making as much. Maybe if people were carpooling more often or on bikes it would save a lot of those terrible greenhouse gasses from getting into our atmosphere. Good interpretation of the graph!

name: Devyn D
comment info: I notice that electricity is the top contributor to greenhouse gasses in the United States. Transportation is the second greatest contributor, and the graph on the right divides this information further by showing that trains, planes, and ships are the greatest contributors from the category of transportation. I wonder why the industry is not one of the highest contributors if it probably uses a significant amount of energy and electricity. A possible headline could be “Greenhouse Gases That Aren’t Actually Green for the Environment.”

name: Jordan
location: St. John the Apostle School Clark, NJ
comment info: I notice how electricity and transportation use more greenhouse gases than industry and agriculture.  I am curious why passenger vehicles use less greenhouse gases then trucks.   The graph shows the estimated number of how much of greenhouse gases each source uses. My Headline is Pass the knowledge of the greenhouse gas.

replies.comment info:
@Jordan I like that your headline suggests that knowledge is a good thing!

The stacked area graph on the right is confusing to a lot of folks.  It actually shows that passenger vehicles are the biggest producer of greenhouse gases, while trucks are the second biggest. Knowing that, give it another look and see if you can figure out how it works.  You can also check out the Stats Nuggets that get posted tomorrow, or do a little research to learn more about stacked area graphs.  Let me know what you figure out!

name: Ms. Treitman's Class
comment info:
Notice:
Passenger vehicles put out the most greenhouse gas seconded by electricity even though electricity was more in the 90's (KW)

Questions:
Is there any way to solve this issue that the world is facing currently? (DC)

Suggestions:
Could we try to even out daily activities - try not to take your car and use different types of transportation, and use of electronics. (AR)

Headline: OOUUU My Lungs Hurt

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Treitman's Class --

Thank you, Ms. Treitman’s Class for these noticings, wonderings, and headline.  

You wonder if there “(i)s there any way to solve this issue that the world is facing currently?”  Well, today’s Boston Globe on the front page had an article “Late, As Always.”  Search for the article by the  headline plus the search term “Boston Globe” to see it.    There you will read about several strategies that the government and companies have used or considered to reduce driving and its greenhouse gas emissions.  Report back to us which strategies you think will be most effective in reducing emissions.

name: Grace R
comment info: This graph shows the top sources of greenhouse gases and how much gas the sources produce.  It also breaks down the different sources of greenhouse gas within transportation. The highest producer of greenhouse gas was electricity until just before 2017. It had previously almost reached 2.5 billion metric tons. Currently, transportation is the highest producer, followed by electricity, industry, and agriculture. Within transportation, passenger vehicles and trucks produce the most gas. In the graph measuring total production, the number of metric tons has gone down after increasing in the 2000s. The amount produced by transportation also decresed before 2017 but has since gone up. I wonder why the amount of greenhouses gases has decreased overall, especially why electricity has decreased do much. I also wonder what caused the dip in transportation and what has caused it to go back up. One possible headline could be "Its Getting Hot in Here: Top Sources of Greenhouse Gases."

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Grace R -

Great noticings and wonderings.  

Looking at the graphs, can you figure out:  Are greenhouse gasses increasing or decreasing now?  How do they compare to 1990 levels?  Explain your reasoning.  

To reduce emissions, which sectors would be the “easiest targets” and how would you get them to be reduced?

name: Lauren AOSE
comment info:
I noticed that electricity sources the largest amount of greenhouse gases. In terms of vehicles, trucks omit the most emissions which isn’t surprising to me. I wonder what this graph would look like if it was showing a different countries emissions. Is American green compared to other nations?
Headline: Biggest Greenhouse Gas Guzzlers

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: @Lauren AOSE  We like your title, it's very creative.  We also think it would be interesting to compare the US graphs with other countries around the world.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Lauren AOSE  We agree that trucks are the largest source of greenhouse gases out of vehicles.

name: Kristine
comment info:
I noticed that there was a small spike in the amount of greenhouse gases emitted in the mid/late 2000s and I wonder what the cause of that was. 

I also noticed that passenger vehicles and trucks are the greatest transportation contributors of greenhouse gas emissions, and I wonder what policies and regulations we (lawmakers) can put in place in order to curb the amount of emissions produced by transportation, especially passenger vehicles and trucks.

Headline: Will electric trucks be the next big thing?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Kristine --
Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  You wonder “what policies and regulations we (lawmakers) can put in place in order to curb the amount of emissions produced by transportation, especially passenger vehicles and trucks.”  What has been done in your community?  What has the State of California done?  

Also, search for the New York Times article “How Cities Are Taming Cars” and the Boston Globe article “Late, As Always”(Add “Boston Globe” to your search terms for this article.)  These articles describe methods that cities and companies have used to encourage drivers to leave their cars at home and use alternative means of transportation.  
Based on what you know from where you live and the articles, what do you think is the strategy that would most likely reduce emissions?  

Maybe you could report back to us on ways we could reduce emissions from cars and trucks?

name: Mr. Kingsbury's class
comment info:
We noticed that the graph is about transportation.

We wonder who designed the graph.

Trains, plains, or auto mobiles.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Mr. Kingsbury's class --

The graph on the right is about the sources of greenhouse gasses from different means of transportation.  Trains, planes, and ships are the gray sectors, but the graph does not show which mean of transportation goes with which gray area.  Which means of transportation do you think is the largest gray sector?  Explain why you think it’s this means of transportation.

The New York Times made these graphs.  They use data from the Environmental Agency, which you can find on the EPA Fast Facts for the National-Level U.S. Greenhouse Gas Inventory (https://tinyurl.com/USGasses).  Take a look.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Mr. Kingsbury's class I like your wondering. I also wonder where the data came from and what the design of the study was like. This is a good reminder to not just take data for face value!

replies.comment info:
HI, @Erica and Nicholas --
I like your start for a headline “Dream Green,” but I don’t see evidence in these graphs about anything“green.”  Maybe add some words to the headline to capture the graph’s ideas.  
Please let us know what you create.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs show the change in the amount of greenhouse gases emissions by industry and by type of transportation.  (How does Thanksgiving travel relate to these graphs?)

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graphs. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be moderated on Wednesday, December 4.  The topic – immigrants and crime.  In the meantime, have a wonderful Thanksgiving holiday.

name: Charlotte
comment info:
Notice: The electricity section used to produce the most amount of greenhouse gasses. Overtime, this dropped and transport now is the biggest producer.
Wonder: I wonder if both charts are stacked charts or if the chart on the left is a different kind of chart. I also wonder what the bottom two lines on the left chart are.
What's Happening: The graphs are showing the top sources of greenhouse gasses in the US. The first graph showing the amount of metric tonnes (in billions) of greenhouse gasses being produced by various sources. The y-axis is the years the information was taken from (1990-2017). The second graph is a breakdown of the transportation section from the first graph.

replies.comment info:
Welcome @Charlotte from Canberra –

You noticed that the amount of greenhouse gasses from electricity has declined since the late 2000s.  The decline started when we had an economic recession in the U.S.  In the graph, do you see this decline in greenhouse gasses in other sectors?  Why do you think that emissions from transportation have recovered and now are increasing but electricity has continued to decline?

About the kind of graphs these are, there is one stacked area graph and one time series line graph.  Which is which?

I, too, wonder what the bottom two lines are on the emissions by sector graph.  What do you think they could be?

Bet you have a catchy headline that captures the main ideas of these graphs?  Please share it with us.

name: Joe
comment info:
I noticed that the amount of greenhouse gases produced by industry and electricity has begun to decline over time, however the amount of greenhouse gases produced by transportation is on the rise and seems to be continuing to do so. I also noticed that the amount of gases produced by agriculture and other causes have stayed fairly flat throughout this whole time. 
I wonder whether or not the rest of the lines such as electricity are also stacked graphs such as transportation or whether that is the entire amount produced. I also wonder why if we've managed to decrease the amount of greenhouse gases produced through electricity and industry, why can't we do the same with transportation?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Joe --

You wonder, “Why if we've managed to decrease the amount of greenhouse gases produced through electricity and industry, why can't we do the same with transportation?”  What could we do to get emissions from transportation to decline?  I’m sure you have ideas that you could share with us.  

Also, search for the New York Times article “How Cities Are Taming Cars” and the Boston Globe article “Late, As Always”(Add Boston Globe to your search terms for this article.)  These articles describe methods that cities and companies have used to encourage drivers to use leave their cars at home and use alternative means of transportation.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: @Joe Joe who? A potential solution to the transportation issue could be more electric vehicles like Tesla.

name: Alex
comment info: I wonder why transportation passed industry in emitting greenhouse gases in the early 90's. Also, I am curious about the dip in the top three sources emissions around 2010, is it a result of the 2008 stock market crash?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Alex --

You are probably correct that the reduction in emissions was due to the 2008 worldwide economic depression.  But, I wonder:  Why did transportation rebound, but electricity and industry did not.  What do you think?

comment info:

replies.comment info:

name: Graceanna
comment info: This graph is tracing the emission of carbon dioxide in the category of transportation. Surprisingly, passenger vehicles emit the most greenhouse gases. While trucks, planes, trains, and ships are larger and probably do emit more gas than a car does, the amount of cars probably outnumber the amount of these other large vehicles. In addition, before 1990, industry and electricity seemed to be the main sources of greenhouse gas emissions, but within the last 27 years, transportation has been on a fairly steady increase. Perhaps people began to buy more cars as more technology was being released. In the second graph, there is a small decline in passenger vehicles' gas emissions  before 2017, and this may be due to an increase of electric cars.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Graceanna Headline: "Transportation Takes the Top"

Good morning, @Graceanna --

You noticed that “there is a small decline in passenger vehicles' gas emissions before 2017, and this may be due to an increase of electric cars.”  But, there are small declines in all means of transportation in the late 2000s.  Why do you think this is so?

I also wonder what percentage of vehicles is electric.  That should be easy to search for online.  Enough to significantly change the direction of the change in emissions?

name: Laura
comment info: The graphs are trying to tell us what the top sources of greenhouse gases did over time in the United States. Did they increase or decrease? What the graph isn't telling us is; why is transportation highlighted in red? Does the graph start from zero?  Are the graphs related?

HI, @Laura --

You ask, “Why is transportation highlighted in red?” and “Are the graphs related?”

Yes!  The graphs are related and it has to do with why transportation is highlighted in red.  Take another look.  Now, what do you notice?

You wonder, “Will transportation greenhouse gasses ever go back down or will it just keep rapidly increasing?”   

What has already been done in NYC to reduce greenhouse gasses?  What else has been discussed?  

Also, search for the New York Times article “How Cities Are Taming Cars” and the Boston Globe article “Late, As Always”(Add “Boston Globe” to your search terms for this article.)  These articles describe methods that cities and companies have used to encourage drivers to leave their cars at home and use alternative means of transportation.  

Based on what you know from where you live and the articles, what do you think is the strategy that would most likely reduce emissions?  Maybe you could report back to us on ways we could reduce emissions from cars and trucks?

What do you notice about NYC?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Jermaine --

Thank you for your noticing.  

Let’s think about saying that “electricity is the majority of the reason for greenhouse gases.”Majority means more than 50%.  Estimate the amount of emissions for the seven sectors shown.  Add them up to get 100%.  Then determine if electricity is a majority of the emissions.  

The graph on the right is a different type of graph.  It’s called a stacked area graph.  Here, the horizontal “strip” represents the amount of emissions.  Which type of transportation emits a majority of emissions?

How about a catchy headline that captures what you have discovered?

comment info: Notice: I notice that over the years we started using materials that helps transport stuff easier and faster.

name: nia
comment info:
noticing : Gasses in our atmosphere comes from transportation in the industry. It´s also increased from 1990s to the mid 2000s. 
wondering: Where is the information really coming from? Can we do something to fix this problem? 
Title: Gasses involving Transportation

name: Liam
comment info:
Title: Sources of greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 to 2017
Wonder: I wondered why electricity spiked up and then had a big downfall and met transportation
Noticing: I noticed that trains, planes, ships, and others had the most greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 to 2017

name: jude rempel
comment info: how have we made the amount of greenhouse gasses emitted by electricity to go down because we are using electricity more than ever now.I notice that the greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture have essentially stayed the same over the years which doesn't really surprise me because the process has stayed the same over the years. and my title is damn we're doing something right for once.

name: Marcos
comment info: i notice that Electricity has gone of from 1990 to about 2012, then i fell down at 2017

name: Brianna B.
comment info:
Notice: I notice that while many people think that cattle is a major source of methane, a major greenhouse gas, much of the greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere come from transportation in the industry, specifically coming from things such as large trucks, trains, planes, and simply passenger vehicles in general. Plus over time the gas emissions have increased.

Wonder: I wonder what we could do to fix the greenhouse gas problem while still having a successful, and thriving economy, because in today’s world everything’s all about money even if It means destroying the very planet that we live on today.

What’s going on in this graph?: 
The graph is showing the main sources of greenhouse gas emissions, and how it has increased from 1990-2017, and what areas come from such as transportation .

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Brianna B. great observations!

name: Ethan
comment info:
The United States emits nearly two metric tons of greenhouse gasses, as shown by the graph, and the amount of greenhouse gasses empires decreases when the economy is in a rough shape. This is shown by the decline in industry and the general time periods where there was an economic slump.

I wonder where this information is gathered from and how it was conducted. I also wonder how the graph compares to other countries such as China, Russia, and India.

“The Alarming Emissions Caused by Travel, What You Can Do,” would be a good title for the graph

name: Jena
comment info: I noticed that the transportation emissions increased steadily from the 1990s to about the mid 2000s, and then finally decrease slightly, but it is not as great a downward trend compared to Electricity and Industry emissions. I wonder if this lack of change in the transportation industry is because more attention in regards to climate change and the emission of greenhouse gases is often focused on those other industries, and the actual adverse impact of transportation emissions is minimized by mainstream media coverage due to the ties and influence that many automobile corporations possess.

name: Sabryna
comment info: Even though there are many advancements in electricity emissions, transportation is still steadily rising. I wonder if the impact of the decrease in electrical emissions will make a difference in the amount of carbon dioxide being released. But even if there is a difference in the number of emissions invading our atmosphere, due to other forms of transportation the carbon dioxide levels will continue to rise.

name: Anthony
comment info: The graph shows a rapid decline in electric emissions while transportation emissions continue to rise slightly but are now the leading source of greenhouse gas emissions. I wonder if the cause for the drop in transportation emissions correlates with a peak in electric emissions, potentially electric cars played a role or there was a larger emphasis placed on electric energy for a short period of time. The second graph on the right shows the transportation emissions by each mode of transportation, this reveals that the leading contributor in transportation emissions are passenger vehicles. Carpool to keep  sea levels down and cars out of pools.

name: Ligma
comment info: I wonder why transportation passed industry in emitting greenhouse gases in the early 90's. Also, I am curious about the dip in the top three sources emissions around 2010.

name: Cassie
comment info: I noticed that transportation emissions dipped around 2010, but began rising again till now. I wonder what caused the emissions to decrease and why they began rising again. I think it may present something that can be done again in order to lower emissions today.

name: Bill
comment info: This article shows that the largest problem when it comes to greenhouse emissions is mostly the large bulk of petroleum-powered cars in the U.S. Buy teslas people, it'll help!

name: Caitlin
comment info: I noticed that all the emission levels dropped around the same time, and I wonder what caused that to happen. I also noticed that the only emission level that stayed down after the drop was electricity. My headline would be “Despite Promising Drop in Emission Levels, Most Are on the Rise Again”

name: willoj
comment info: The graphs could of been more specific with axis labels and define each carbon emmsison

name: Ian Smith
comment info: I noticed that around the greenhouse gas emissions in industry and and electricity began to decrease in the early to late 2000s. Meanwhile the emissions from transportation have slowly increased and now leads in greenhouse emissions. This makes me wonder why people blame the big evil coal and natural gas companies.

name: isaac
comment info: Ive noticed that the transportation has become increasingly inefficient, while electricity has dropped significantly.

name: Rachel
comment info: I notice that transportation is a large source of greenhouse gas emission that is slowly overtaking electricity and produces almost 2 billion metric tons per year.In the transportation sector passenger vehicles produce the most greenhouse gases.What I wonder is  if by reducing the use of passenger vehicles and searching for more sustainable ways to power electricity ho beneficial would that be in slowing climate change

name: Claire
comment info: I noticed that transportation emissions have pretty steadily risen, with some fluctuations. While other sources of carbon emissions have either leveled off or began decreasing like electricity. But still the amount of emissions from transportation, industry, and electricity are extremely high.

name: Daisy
comment info: I notice that the Industry emissions are incredibly high. When you consider carbon emissions it is easy to recognize cars, planes, and transportation as big emitters. It is more challenging to recognize the sheer amount of fossil fuels going into factory and industry production, as we do not see it happening right in front of us as often.

name: Olivier
comment info: I noticed that greenhouse gases from transportation in recent years have slightly increased while gases from electricity and less notably industry seem to decrease. I wonder if this is because better management of electricity, but higher population and more use of cars, or if other advances in technology have been made to decrease electricity and industry gases, but not transportation. Planes, trains, and automobiles.

name: Cooper
comment info: I noticed that while electricity has been advanced to become more efficient, transportation hasn't gotten any more efficient.  I wonder if the slight increase in emissions from vehicles is from an increase of people using them and not the efficiency of them.  Headline is "Why cars are bad"

name: collin
comment info: I noticed of the four categories only transportation seems to be increasing its emissions. I wonder why the transportation emissions went sharply down and now are rising again.  Headline: There's no escaping transportation greenhouse gases, no matter how fast you drive.

name: Valeria Melgoza
comment info: Modes of Transportation emit more green house gases than industries. I've always felt that it was these mass industries that were doing the most damage to our planet but after looking at the chart, passenger vehicles are to blame for the emission of green house gases.

name: Ryan
comment info: I wonder why transportation passed industry in emitting greenhouse gases in the early 90's. Also, I am curious about the dip in the top three sources emissions around 2010.

name: Avery Haag
comment info: Hey so I was just thinking how its kind of odd that all the comments on this post all say pretty much the same thing, but then I realized that your corporation decides what public opinions are allowed on their website, and it all started making more sense.

name: Rebecca
comment info: I thought it was interesting how the main focus of the chart is the emissions made through transportation.  I shows how they decided to aim the problem at something people can moderate.

name: Cole
comment info: I noticed that transportation has just become the leading source of greenhouse gasses. I wonder what changes were made to electricity sources to make them produce less greenhouse gasses and if these changes are applicable to transportation. Headline: Transportation Is Now The Leader in Greenhouse Gas Emmisions.

name: sara
comment info: I noticed that the increase of transportation and the development of how  transportation changed made a big impact on this graph.  the  decreased  of the  electricity made the greenhouse gasses also increase every year more then the agriculture.

name: Erin Carr
comment info: We noticed that Transportation has just exceeded Electricity for amount of greenhouse gas emissions produced per year. We wonder if this is due to a lot of effort towards renewable energy sources for electricity, and a lack of attention towards renewable fuel/energy for transportation. TITLE: Greenhouse Gas Growth

name: Nicole and Luke
comment info: Electricity seems to be steadily declining as the leading source of Greenhouse Gas emissions, as transportation has taken a slight lead. We wonder if this is due to the implementation of energy-efficient alternatives which have come out in recent years such as solar panels and LED lights. A catchy headline for this graph would be 'What's Warming Up The Greenhouse?'

name: Elliot Topper
comment info:
I notice the transportation recently overtook electricity as the top source of greenhouse gases in the US.
I wonder why transportation emissions peaked in about 2005.
Headline: Trucks: The Pollution of the Future

name: Evan and Riley
comment info:
We noticed there was a peak in emissions at about year 2000. It was previously increasing to that peak, and afterwards dropped off sharply. However, it seems to be increasing again.
Electricity emissions specifically followed that same trend, which may have been caused by the increased use of renewable sources.

We wonder what the graph looked like previous to 1990, and what the trend of electricity was beforehand.

Our headline is, "Got gas?"

name: Mr. Fleming
comment info: From 7th grade student:  I noticed that since about 2010, electricity emissions have gone down significantly. I wonder if this is because of new technology for clean renewable energy.

name: Ms. Treitman
comment info: I am a teacher looking to use this program in my class next week and wanted to see how the comments portion works.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Ms. Treitman As you hopefully can see, it's easy for students to register for free - as long as they are 13 years old or older. On our end, we read every comment, and then approve the ones that meet NYT commenting standards. So sometimes there is a short lag between when students submit a comment, and when it is approved to be published. We look forward to seeing your students join the discussion.
